repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Throttled FileSystem through broker.
body:
This is a large PR covering throttled (and in general) instrumented file systems obtained from a `SharedResourcesBroker`. Luckily, a lot of the code is boilerplate and refactoring, so it's not actually THAT big.

Main Changes
==========

Implicit Broker
-------------
Introduced the concept of an implicit `SharedResourcesBroker`. This is necessary for using brokers without having to explicitly define them in the application structure, which might be too invasive. Basically, there is a singleton implicit broker whose configuration is loaded from environment variables, java properties, a configuration file in the classpath, and possibly Hadoop configuration. Furthermore, applications can inject a custom implicit broker which is thread-local and is inherited by children threads.

Instrumented File Systems
-------------------------
Changed the previous `Instrumented*FileSystem` for a slightly different structure.

An `InstrumentedFileSystem` is a `FileSystem` decorator that instantiates a regular `FileSystem` and decorates it using a variety of `FileSystemInstrumentationFactory`s in the classpath (for example, metrics, throttling, etc.). This involves a slightly convoluted structure:
* `FileSystemDecorator` is a base decorator for `FileSystem`s. It allows optionally switching the schemes in the uri. The file is very large, but it is mostly mechanical.
* `FileSystemInstrumentation` is just an extension of `FileSystemDecorator` that does not switch scheme. It is intended as a base for other instrumentations.
* `FileSystemInstrumentationFactory` is the actual class that should be extended for instrumentations. 
* `FileSystemFactory` is a `SharedResourceFactory` that builds an underlying `FileSystem`, then decorates it with any `FileSystemInstrumentationFactory`s that exist in the classpath.
* `InstrumentedFileSystem` and subclasses (`InstrumentedHDFSFileSystem`, etc.) are a different convenient way of getting a `FileSystem` with instrumentations. Basically, users can either use an instrumented scheme (e.g. `instrumented-hdfs`), or use the property `fs.<scheme>.impl` to one of the instrumented file systems. The `InstrumentedFileSystem` will use the implicit broker in that context to return an instrumented `FileSystem`.

There are currently two `FileSystemInstrumentationFactory`s: `MetricsFileSystemInstrumentation` which adds metrics to all fs calls, and `ThrottledFileSystem` which adds throttling.

title: TIMESTAMP fields of the initial schema in gobblin-metastore
body:
As of mysql 5.6.6 `TIMESTAMP` columns are `NOT NULL` by default which means we should assign a `DEFAULT` value to them. My understanding of the modified code was that they could be `NULL`, so I've made appropriate modifications to the schema.

Without this modification, there is an error during creating tables.

title: Added property with scheduler service startup timeout
body:
Hello,

I'm trying to run Gobblin in standalone cluster mode on our dev environment. I don't want to use Azkaban or Oozie as a scheduler, so I configured Quartz in cluster mode with MySQL backend. Because of not so good performance of mysql cluster on dev environment or physical distance between current mysql master and Gobblin installation, I've encountered `TimeoutException`s during job scheduler startup on Gobblin master. After diving in the code, I've noticed that in `startUp` method of `JobScheduler` there is such a piece of code: `this.scheduler.awaitRunning(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS);`. That was not enough to establish the connection by Quartz which produces  stacktrace below:

```
Exception in thread "GobblinHelixJobScheduler STARTING" java.lang.IllegalStateException: Scheduler service is not running.
	at gobblin.scheduler.JobScheduler.startUp(JobScheduler.java:178)
	at gobblin.cluster.GobblinHelixJobScheduler.startUp(GobblinHelixJobScheduler.java:82)
	at com.google.common.util.concurrent.AbstractIdleService$2$1.run(AbstractIdleService.java:54)
	at com.google.common.util.concurrent.Callables$3.run(Callables.java:93)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
Caused by: java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException: Timed out waiting for  [STARTING] to reach the RUNNING state. Current state: STARTING
	at com.google.common.util.concurrent.AbstractService.awaitRunning(AbstractService.java:295)
	at com.google.common.util.concurrent.AbstractIdleService.awaitRunning(AbstractIdleService.java:184)
	at gobblin.scheduler.JobScheduler.startUp(JobScheduler.java:176)
	... 4 more
```

Introducing new property: `jobscheduler.startup.timeout` with default value of `1` was the simplest solution that fixes the issue. Please let me know if it meets your standards :)

title: Add feature to QueryBasedExtractor to be able to retry from the first iterator
body: Current behavior for failed QueryBasedExtractor task is that it always retries from the failed iterator. But in some cases, for example, downloading chunks from a long lasting stream with connection, the retry task cannot restart from the middle(failed iterator), it has to restart from the beginning(Rebuild the connection, and re-download in this example.). The PR adds this feature to the QueryBasedExtractor, and also corrects/resets the downloaded records count for the retry task.

title: Add one more option for distcping Hive-Registered table
body:
Previously the only flow is : Copy the data into new Path on filesystem, deregister the original hive table and create a new one.  

Add one more option for the case where table deregistration is not preferable, but change the corresponding data location on filesystem only.  

Status: Require validation from Hive side, e.g. Changing the permission/privilege in the original table, run the new flow, see whether the hive table still keep those permission/privilege setting as before, although the data location has been updated.

title: Added fail-fast option to CopyableDatasetRequestor (disabled by default)
body:
Currently when there's failure getting dataset in CopyableDatasetRequestor, it logs the error and continue to perform distcp and makes job status success overall. 
This change will have user to choose to make the job fail fast so that failure from CopyableDatasetRequestor will make the job fail immediately.

- Integration test passed.

job property snippet:
gobblin.copy.CopyableDatasetRequestor.failFast=true

title: Throttling server refuses extremely large requests, can provide fewer
body:
than requested permits.

This PR improves the throttling server:
* Previously, large requests would just block for a long time, eventually timing out on the client. This is obviously not useful.
* Introduced a few heuristics to the server:
** If a request cannot be satisfied within timeout, return immediately.
** If a request has a minimum useful permits lower than the ideal requested permits, and the ideal requested permits cannot be satisfied quickly, try to return a lower number of permits.
** If the throttler is under-utilized, e.g. there are a lot of stored permits, then it may return more permits than requested.
* Since Guava `RateLimiter` does not allow extension or fine control, implemented a custom `TokenBucket` algorithm.
* No longer use straight `Limiter`s in the server, as the needs are different than in a client. Instead, use `ThrottlingPolicies` (which may or may not wrap a `Limiter`).
* Throttling client sends an ideal and minimum number of requested permits.

title: Fixing travis build from failing
body:
findBugsMain was failing for gobblin-runtime due to which travis build was failing. Fixed two reasons for failure:
1) Trying to synchronize on an interned string. So instead of using "LOCK" we should use either new String("LOCK") or new Object().
If we use new String("LOCK"), then findBugs will fail stating performance issue and will ask to use "LOCK" instead of new String("LOCK");
2) Casting in equals method. It states that if other is not an instance of this, then return false. Reformatted the code.

title: Remove explicit State dependency on hadoop.io.Writable
body:
Create a new WritableShim interface that serializable objects can depend on without explicitly depending on hadoop.io.Writable. This is one step to get hadoop out of gobblin-api's dependency tree (there are still a few files in here which depend on hadoop.fs.Path that I haven't looked at yet).

Major pieces:

 - Create a `WritableShim` interface which mirrors Hadoop's Writable without explicitly depending on it. Change State to depend on this
 - Create a `WritableShimSerialization` class (in a different module) that implements Hadoop's Serialization interface. Update FsStateStore and ParallelRunner to add this to Hadoop serialization config.

 I had originally tried to solve this by creating a `WritableDecorator` that implements `Writable` and using that everywhere, but this breaks backwards compatibility. The SequenceFile stores the key/val class names in the file itself, so it sees that the value class name in an old state store is State, it was expecting WritableDecorator, and then blows up.

title: Can run custom tasks in Gobblin.
body:
This PR allows running custom tasks in Gobblin. 

To use custom tasks, implement a `TaskFactory` and use `TaskUtils.setTaskFactoryClass(WorkUnitState, Class<? extends TaskFactory>` in the `Source`. Tasks need to implement `TaskIFace`.

title: Enable partitioning based on source info + partitioned metadata writes
body:
@ibuenros @shirshanka 

- Fix an issue in DatePartitionedAvroFileSource where the code would not
resolve paths properly if the prefix config property was empty
- Enhance the AvroFileSource to send along the partition it extracted
in WorkUnitState
- Create a WorkUnitStateWriterPartitioner that will partition an
incoming record solely based on WorkUnitState
- Update writers to set any partition paths they use in an internal
PARTITION_PATH_KEY
- Update BaseDataPublisher to collect partition information and publish
metadata files in each partition directory if the metadata output
directory is not specifically configured somewhere else.
- Update BaseDataPublisher to publish metadata _after_ publishing data.
If this isn't done - and partitions are enabled - then the code that
publishes all of the data files ends up publishing them as
subdirectories into the partition path. (Eg you get
/out/2017-01-01/2017-01-01/data.json).

title: Functionality for record-by-record pipelines / extraction of code

- Extract a bunch of logic that was in FsDataWriter out to a GlobalMetadataCollector object which can be re-used in other places
- Create a MetadataWriterWrapper that surrounds other writer objects to collect metadata records that flow through
- Create a few Metadata wrapper for existing converters
- Fix a config issue where both the Encryption converter and the SimpleDataWriter were looking at writer.encrypt.* to figure out if they should do anything or not; change the converter class to look at a different set of config

title: Throttle underlying input streams.
body:
The main point of this PR is that we should throttle underlying streams instead of the streams that Gobblin replication sees. For example, if a replication flow does on-the-fly compression / decompression, we want to limit the bytes per second that are actually going through the network, not the output of compression / decompression.

Few changes:
* Introduce metered streams to measure bytes processed in an input/output stream.
* Introduce throttled input stream that is transparently throttled, and a `StreamThrottler` to create the throttled input streams.
* Added the concept of a BrokerView that allows a higher scoped immutable view of a broker. This is necessary for correct functionality of some factories.
* There is no reason replication should use `FSDataInputStream`, so changed to use `InputStream` (this is a backwards incompatible change, but it was overly restrictive).

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Extract modules
body:
Refactor the Crypto, Codec, and Metadata concepts out into their own smaller modules so we aren't bloating core and core-base; some of these modules could potentially be included in other projects later.

New modules:

- `gobblin-metadata` contains Metadata related classes
- `gobblin-codecs` contains non-crypto related codecs
- `gobblin-crypto` contains crypto code
- `gobblin-crypto-provider` is a tiny module that links `gobblin-runtime` with `gobblin-crypto`. It's super tiny but exists so that `gobblin-crypto` can retain a very small dependency tree.

`EncryptionFactory` is changed to use `java.util.ServiceLoader` to dynamically register encryption plugins. This is a pattern that probably will be re-used in other cases.

A ton of files have changed, but most of the changes are mechanical:
 - Fixing-up import statements
 - Replace a few hardcoded creations of RotatingAESCodec with factory calls
 - Replaced `@Slf4j` annotations with specific instantiations so we don't need to take a Lombok dependency
 - Replace `SingleRecordIterable` with `Collections.singleton()` so we don't take dependencies on `gobblin-core`

title: Added retention to gobblin-compliance
body:
Work flow of Retetention:
1) ComplianceRetentionJob.run() is called by by the ComplianceAzkabanJob.
2) ComplianceRetentionJob will find all the HivePartitionDataset(s) for which retention needs to run. Note that here HivePartitionDataset refers to the original hive partitions not the backups/staging partitions.
3) For each HivePartitionDataset, HivePartitionVersionFinder will find associated versions. Here versions refer to a backup/staging partition corresponding to an original partition.
4) A HivePartitionVersionPolicy will be called to shortlist the versions which needs to deleted/moved. All the backups are moved to a backup directory after 2 days so that inflight queries won't get affected.
5) On each shortlisted version, a cleaner/reaper will run. Cleaner for deletion of backups. Reaper for deletion of staging and moving of backups to backup directory.

title: Batch level metadata support
body:
- Each writer keeps track of some GlobalMetadata (which for now is only TransferEncoding).
- BaseDataPublisher merges all of these metadata objects together using the GlobalMetadataMerger, and writes the merged data out to disk if the appropriate config is set
- Add a JsonUtil class to hold Jackson objects so we aren't constructing them all over the place. This will also let us hang config settings off there if we figure out there are good defaults to set.

To follow in future PRs:
 - Support to set GlobalMetadata from config/an arbitrary retriever
 - Allow sources + converters to optionally set global metadata
 - Per-record metadata

title: Bug fixes for avro2orc
body:
1) Changed UpdateNotFoundException to UncheckedExecutionException in ValidationJob
    UpdateNotFoundException extends RuntimeException. All the RuntimeExceptions are wrapped as   UncheckedExecutionException by com.google.common.cache.LocalCache. Hence the job fails whenever UpdateNotFoundException is thrown which defeats the purpose of catching it.

2) Replacing LinkedHashMap for storing evolved HiveColumns. This correponds to the issue https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/issues/1672

3) Adding the property to skip setting group for the destination dataset same as source. This is needed because if the owner is not a part of the group (there are various reasons why such a thing can happen at the first place), then the task will fail.

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Forks: Making primitive types copyable by default, tests and bug fixes
body:
Currently, record types must implement Copyable to participate in fork-based pipelines. 
This PR relaxes this requirement by adding support for byte[] and immutable types like String etc. 

There are a few notable un-filed issues that were discovered that this PR also fixes. 
a) Fork specific config (typically prefixed by numerical branch ids e.g. writer.staging.dir.0) were being mangled due to transformation from Properties -> TypeSafe Config -> Properties. TypeSafe Config surrounds numeric looking tokens with quotes, leading to these config keys looking like writer.staging.dir."0" in TaskState. This PR works around this by stripping all quotes from keys in the Properties bag when transiting through ConfigUtils::configToProperties

b) #1596 inadvertently introduced a bug in Task.java where forked records weren't being sent into the correct fork.

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: ThreadPool leak in HttpWriter
body:
A Gobblin job that outputs data to http, for instance to a REST endpoint using `gobblin.writer.http.RestJsonWriterBuilder` returns successfully as expected. 
However, after subsequent runs such errors may be seen in the Yarn container logs:
```
Error: A JNI error has occurred, please check your installation and try again
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.InternalError: java.io.FileNotFoundException: 
/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_77.jdk/Contents/Home/jre/lib/ext/localedata.jar
(Too many open files in system)
```
The `YarnChild` processes are still running for each previous job and they never terminate.
In the thread dumps I see that **DestroyJavaVM** just desperately waits for other threads to complete.
After analyzing the heap dump, it turned out that `singleThreadPool` in `gobblin.writer.http.AbstractHttpWriter` is not shut down at all, thus it can never be reclaimed by the GC.
Also, when `gobblin.instrumented.writer.InstrumentedDataWriterBase#close` calls to `RestJsonWriter#close`, nothing happens as close is not overridden in any of RestjsonWriter, HttpWriter, AbstractHttpWriter.

The patch tries to address this issue by adding `AbstractHttpWriter#close` which calls to cleanup() to close CloseableHttpClient and ListeningExecutorService objects.

title: Added metrics to rest.li limiter.
body:
Changes:

* Created a `MetricContextFactory` for broker, along with a `MetricContextKey` and a unit test.
* Rest.li Limiter supports emitting metrics. The factory automatically acquires a metric context from the broker.

* In Gobblin runtime, `WorkUnitState` gets a broker builder instead of a pre-built broker so it can inject its own custom configurations (not done currently). Eventually, I would want to replace all `MetricContext`s in gobblin runtime for ones acquired from the broker.
* Added a scope id to the `ScopeInstance` interface.
* Minor changes to generics in broker (fixes compiler/ide warnings)

title: Fix to stop travis build from failing
body:
Travis build was failing because of two reasons. If something else fails I will add it in this PR
1) Package junit was not found for modules gobblin-data-management and gobblin-ingestion
  Fix is to add junit as a dependency.
2) Once above is fixed it starts failing due to findbugs
Bug type NP_NULL_PARAM_DEREF_ALL_TARGETS_DANGEROUS (click for details) 
In class gobblin.cluster.ScheduledJobConfigurationManager
In method gobblin.cluster.ScheduledJobConfigurationManager.fetchJobSpecs()
Called method gobblin.cluster.JobConfigurationManager.postDeleteJobConfigArrival(String, Properties)
At ScheduledJobConfigurationManager.java:[line 138]
Argument 2 is definitely null but must not be null
Definite null passed to dangerous method call target gobblin.cluster.JobConfigurationManager.postDeleteJobConfigArrival(String, Properties)

Fix is to add new Properties() instead of passing null

repo.name: gobblin

title: [GOBBLIN-50] Every time createJdbcSource() is called, new JdbcProvider is assigned to this.jdbcSource.
body:
Every time createJdbcSource() is called, new JdbcProvider is assigned to 'this.jdbcSource'. It means that it lose exist jdbcSource. 
Therefore, even though closeConnection() is called, lost connections from this.jdbcSource remains connected.
So, I moved createJdbcSource(), this.jdbcSource.getConnection() to construct of JdbcExtractor.

I'm using a gobblin-core as a module of web application not a batch.
The more JdbcSource is executed, the more connections will cause problems. (The number of connections become a maximum number of allowed connections soon.)

title: AsyncWriterManager not to be retried by RetryWriter
body:
(Integration test passed.)

AsyncWriterManager is not designed to be retried by RetryWriter because AsyncWriterManager has its own retry implementation or it can delegate to the writer itself.

Throwing NonTransientException, RetryWriter won't retry.
